\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town B } \\

\hline No & \( 57 \) \\
\hline

ConstructName: Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
AnswerAText: \( 82 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 27^{\text {th }} \) term
AnswerBText: \( 27 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 82^{\text {nd }} \) term
AnswerCText: \( 82 \) is not in the sequence because \( 27 \) is an integer
AnswerDText: Eliza's method does not answer this question
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term

The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
AnswerAText: ![This pattern is the same as Pattern 4: it is made up of 9 squares as a 4 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
AnswerBText: ![This pattern is made up of 11 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
AnswerCText: ![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then 2 extra squares on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
AnswerDText: ![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle, and one more square to the right of that one.]()

ConstructName: Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division
QuestionText: This is how Teddy calculates the answer to \( 600 \div 25 \) mentally "There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in 100. I then multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 6 \) to get \( 24 \). So \( 600 \) divided by \( 25 \) is \( 24 \)" Teddy uses the same method to calculate \( 800 \div 25 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
AnswerAText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 8 \) 
So the answer is \( 32 \)
AnswerBText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)
AnswerCText:
There are \( 6 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 6 \) by \( 4 \) 
So the answer is \( 24 \)
AnswerDText:
There are \( 8 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \)
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: Does not copy a given method accurately
MisconceptionCtext: nan

ConstructName: Construct an angle of 60° using a ruler and a compass
QuestionText: Which of the following best describes how to construct an angle of \( 60^{\circ} \) using a ruler and a pair of compasses?
AnswerAText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width equal to the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Draw a straight line from the ends of each line to where the arcs intersect 
- Bisect the angle created
AnswerBText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width at least the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line and below from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line
- Join up where the lines intersect
- Bisect the angle created
AnswerCText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width equal to the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Draw a straight line from the ends of each line to where the arcs intersect
AnswerDText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width at least the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line and below from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Join up where the lines intersect
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Believes constructing a perpendicular gives an angle of 60 degrees

Pattern 2 is made up of 2 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 10 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to the other rectangle). 
Pattern 3 is made up of 3 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 14 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to another rectangle).]() Tom says the number of circles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be

Who do you agree with?

ConstructName: Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle
QuestionText: Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side?
AnswerAText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw a line \( 50 \mathrm{~cm} \) long that starts at the same end of the line and goes through the dot.
- Join up the end of this line with the other end of the \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) line.
AnswerBText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Set the compass width to \( 40 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from one end of the line
- Set the compass width to \( 50 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from the other end of the line
- Join up the ends of the line to the intersection of the arcs with straight lines
AnswerCText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle
AnswerDText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the other end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Draws both angles at the same end of the line when constructing a triangle

 Pair \( 1 \)

Isaac is trying to solve the equation on the right. \( 15=\frac{1+k}{4} \) Here are his steps. Step \( 1: \) \(
60=1+k
\)

Step \( 2: \) \(
61=k
\) Which steps, if any, are correct?
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.
MisconceptionCtext: When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.
MisconceptionDtext: Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions

ConstructName: Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer
QuestionText: ![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +5 going from -1 up to 4]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
MisconceptionAtext: Believes we move down a number line when we add
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Believes the number of jumps between two numbers on a numberline represents the sum of those 2 numbers
MisconceptionDtext: Believes a negative number can be replaced with its positive equivalent when answering an addition problem from a numberline

MisconceptionBtext: Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry

Jo and Paul are arguing about rounding.
Jo says \( \mathbf{1 2 0 6 . 9 7 8} \) rounded to the nearest hundred is \( \mathbf{1 2 0 0} \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan

ConstructName: Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places

ConstructName: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing simultaneous equations Tom says you need to add these equations to eliminate \( y \)
\(\begin{array}{r}
4 x-3 y=12 \\
x+3 y=15
\end{array}\) Katie says you need to add these equations to eliminate \( y \)
\(\begin{array}{r}
4 x+3 y=12 \\
x-3 y=15
\end{array}\) Who is correct?
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: nan

ConstructName: Sketch, or identify a sketch, of a line given in the form y = mx + c, where m is negative

AnswerDText: ![2 axes with a negative gradient and a negative y intercept]()
MisconceptionAtext: When given the equation of a straight line, believes the first term always gives the gradient, even when the first term is actually c
MisconceptionBtext: When given the equation of a straight line, believes the first term always gives the gradient, even when the first term is actually c

MisconceptionDtext: Believes that in y=mx+c, m is the y-intercept

QuestionText:
Cally wants to use the function machine below to solve this problem:

I think of a number, double it, subtract 5, and the answer is \( 23 \).

Which of the following should replace the star? ![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and has "input" written above it. The next 2 rectangles are empty and the final rectangle on the right has a purple star inside it and has "output" written above it.]()
MisconceptionAtext: When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.
MisconceptionBtext: Does not understand where to place inputs/ operations/ outputs when drawing a function machine
MisconceptionCtext: Does not understand where to place inputs/ operations/ outputs when drawing a function machine

ConstructName: Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
QuestionText:
What sign would make this statement true?
\(
\frac{4}{6} ? \frac{10}{15}
\)
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: Believes that fractions with larger denominators are greater in size
MisconceptionCtext: nan

ConstructName: Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator
QuestionText:
Simplify the following, if possible
\(
\frac{5 m-10}{m^{2}+3 m-10}
\)
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Does not know how to simplify algebraic fractions

ConstructName: Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer
QuestionText:
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{5} \div 2
\)
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: when dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies the numerator by the integer
MisconceptionDtext: When dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies both the numerator and denominator by the integer

ConstructName: Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph
QuestionText:
Jadon decides to go for a run.
The graph on the right shows Jadon's speed in metres per second \( (s) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the negative sloping section of the graph is \( 0.8 \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.8 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with s on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
AnswerAText: Jadon is travelling at a speed of \( 0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
AnswerBText: Jadon is decelerating at a rate of \( 0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)
AnswerDText: Jadon is accelerating at a rate of \( 0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)
MisconceptionAtext: Believes the gradient of a speed-time graph is the speed
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Believes a downward slope on a speed-time graph shows positive acceleration

ConstructName: Sketch curves in the form (x + a)(x + b) indicating where they cross the axes
QuestionText: \( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) \( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis? Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis?
MisconceptionAtext: Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket
MisconceptionBtext: Believes that the y intercept is where y = 0
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving roots
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing calculations involving square roots.

Tom says \( \sqrt{16}+\sqrt{9}=5 \)

Katie says \( \sqrt{16+9}=5 \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: When adding roots, adds the numbers under the roots

ConstructName: Find the nth term rule for an ascending fractional linear sequence
QuestionText:
\( \frac{1}{24}, \frac{1}{12}, \frac{1}{8}, \frac{1}{6}, \ldots \) When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the rectangle? ![nth-term rule:
\[
\frac{1}{24} n
\] followed by a purple rectangle. ]()
MisconceptionAtext: Uses first term as numerical part of nth term rule
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: nan

ConstructName: Carry out a subtraction problem with positive integers where the answer is less than 0
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are trying to write calculations based on the diagram below.

Tom writes: \( 15-20=-5 \)

Katie writes: \( (-5)+20=15 \)

Who is correct? ![Number line with an arrow marked -20 going from 15 to -5]()
MisconceptionAtext: Does not recognise that addition is the inverse operation of subtraction
MisconceptionBtext: Does not recognise that subtracting a larger number from a smaller number will give a negative answer
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Does not understand the diagram given in the question

ConstructName: Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence
QuestionText:
A sequence is formed using the rule

Square the position and add \( 5 \)

What is the third term in the sequence?
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling
MisconceptionCtext: When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the next term

ConstructName: Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for the curve y = x3 + c
QuestionText:
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{x}^{\mathbf{3}} \) ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & W \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() What should replace the star?
MisconceptionAtext: Adds the index to the number
MisconceptionBtext: Multiplies by the index
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Writes the index as a digit on the end of a number

ConstructName: Calculate distance where speed and time are in the appropriate units
QuestionText:
This displacement-time graph shows \( 10 \) seconds of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What distance should replace the star? ![The graph has its vertical axis labelled Distance (m) and it has no scale written except for a star three squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 in even steps.
The graph is a straight line sloping down from (0, star) to (10, 0).
]()
MisconceptionAtext: Believes scales on graphs must match on both axes
MisconceptionBtext: Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10
MisconceptionCtext: Believes distance = speed/time

ConstructName: Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages
MisconceptionAtext: Converts a fraction to a percentage by writing the numerator followed by the denominator
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Converts fraction to percentage by putting % sign after the denominator

ConstructName: Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention
QuestionText:
Simplify, if possible:
\(
a \times 4
\)
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: Writes the variable before the coefficient in an algebraic term
MisconceptionCtext: Thinks multiplying a variable by a number is the same as raising that variable to the power of that number

ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed
QuestionText: The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is ![Triangle with base labelled b and perpendicular height labelled h]() \( A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h) \) Rearrange this to make the base, \( b \), the subject.
MisconceptionAtext: Believes they can change the subject of a formula just by swapping two letters
MisconceptionBtext: Believes dividing by a unit fraction is equivalent to dividing by its reciprocal
MisconceptionCtext: nan

ConstructName: Given the distance travelled, complete missing values on a speed-time graph
QuestionText:
![A speed-time graph. The vertical axis is labelled Speed (mph), with no scale labelled but 4 squares up is marked v.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (hours) and the scale is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in even steps.
The graph first has a horizontal line from (0,v) to (2,v) and then a sloped line from (2,v) to (4,0).]() Work out the speed \( v \) if the distance travelled is \( 90 \) miles.
MisconceptionAtext: Thinks the shape of the graph does not affect the area calculation
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: nan

ConstructName: Convert between l and  cm³
QuestionText:
Complete this statement:
\( 4 \) litres \( = \)_________ \( \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)
MisconceptionAtext: Thinks 1l = 1 cubic centimetre
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Thinks 1l = 100 cubic centimetres

ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed
QuestionText:
The formula for finding the average speed is

\(
\text { speed }(S)=\frac{\text { distance }(D)}{\text { time }(T)}
\)

Which of the following are not correct?
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Does not know how to simplify algebraic fractions

ConstructName: Calculate the median as an average from an odd numbered list of data
SubjectName: Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data
QuestionText:
What is the median of the following numbers?
\( 2,2,4,7,10 \)
MisconceptionAtext: Finds the mean instead of the median
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Finds the mode instead of the median
MisconceptionDtext: When finding the median for an odd numbered data set, find the midpoint of two values rather than giving the middle value

ConstructName: Identify when it is appropriate to use a line graph
QuestionText: Which of the following situations would a line graph be the most appropriate to use?
AnswerAText: Showing the number of brothers and sisters children in a class have
AnswerBText: Showing what time each member of a family went to bed last night
AnswerCText: Showing how the traffic levels in a village have changed over time
AnswerDText: Showing the numbers of each type of animal in a zoo
MisconceptionAtext: Does not understand that a line graph shows a relationship between 2 variables
MisconceptionBtext: Does not understand that a line graph shows a relationship between 2 variables
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Does not understand that a line graph shows a relationship between 2 variables

ConstructName: Read values off a displacement-time graph
QuestionText:
This graph shows the displacement of a ball from a starting point at various times.
How far did the ball travel between \( 1 \) and \( 2 \) seconds? ![A displacement versus time graph]() This graph displacem from a start
MisconceptionAtext: When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points.
MisconceptionBtext: When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points.
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Adds instead of subtracts when asked to find the difference

ConstructName: Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(1-4 v=3-9 v\)

Tom says you can write: \( 1+5 v=3 \)

Katie says you can write: \( -4 v=2-9 v \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Does not realise that to maintain balance in an equation they must add or subtract the same amount from both sides

ConstructName: Round integers to the nearest 10
SubjectName: Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)
QuestionText: What is \( 326 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
MisconceptionAtext: Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)
MisconceptionBtext: Rounds down instead of up
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)

ConstructName: Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: Paige, Kaci and David want to find the area of the school playground. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape made up of two rectangles.  Dimensions are 6 metres by 12 metres and also 4 metres by 8 metres. Two sides do not have measurements so need to be deduced]()
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face
MisconceptionCtext: Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape

ConstructName: Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Believes dividing a positive by a negative gives a positive answer

ConstructName: Calculate the range from a list of data
SubjectName: Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data
QuestionText:
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
1,5,5,17,-6
\]
MisconceptionAtext: Finds the mode rather than the range
MisconceptionBtext: To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract
MisconceptionCtext: nan
MisconceptionDtext: Does not include negative numbers when calculating a range

ConstructName: Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1
SubjectName: Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes
QuestionText:
Shape \( Q \) is an enlargement of shape \( P \).
What calculation works out the constant of proportionality from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \) ? ![To similar star shapes labelled P and Q. They have the same side labelled for P it is 3cm and for Q it is 11cm]()
MisconceptionAtext: When calculating a scale factor, thinks the division is the other way around.
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: When calculating a scale factor, multiplies instead of dividing.
MisconceptionDtext: When calculating a scale factor, thinks they need to subtract rather than divide.

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division
QuestionText:
What does the following equal?
\[
8-7+10 \times 3
\]
MisconceptionAtext: nan
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)
MisconceptionDtext: Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order

ConstructName: Distinguish between congruency and similarity
QuestionText: Tom and Katie are discussing congruence and similarity. Who is correct? Tom says these two squares are congruent ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]() Katie says these two squares are similar ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]()
MisconceptionAtext: Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes
MisconceptionDtext: Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes

ConstructName: Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Jo says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) anticlockwise"

Paul says: "a rotation of \( +270^{\degree} \) about \( (-1,1)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two trapeziums drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, one space to the right and one space up from the origin. Trapezium P has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-4,1). Trapezium Q has the coordinates: (-4,-2) (-4,0) (-3,0) and (-1,-2).]()
MisconceptionAtext: Forgets to give the centre of rotation
MisconceptionBtext: nan
MisconceptionCtext: Forgets to give the centre of rotation
MisconceptionDtext: Does not know about the + notation for directions in rotations
